13. IMHO, some current efforts at the DOE on GenIV nuclear ignore this dynamic, by aiming to vastly expand the number of reactor designs that get approved. I understand that impetus. But unless you get high volume production on a specific design, don't expect it to get cheap.

12. If you want nuclear to thrive and get cheap, you have to have a plan for how specific reactor designs will get built again and again and again, possibly hundreds of times, to get that learning rate.

11. Jumbo size isn't the only reason that megaproject nuclear (gigawatt scale) has gotten more expensive. Regulation & public fear play a role. And the decimation of the supply chain plays a role. If you build a very small number of reactors, of any size, they'll be expensive.

10. I do still have hope for small modular nuclear reactors (SMRs). But it's chicken and egg. At some critical number of units manufactured, costs will get low and predictable. But who will order the first few tens (to maybe hundred) of expensive units? That's the question.

A couple addenda to this thread, specific to nuclear:

9. I don't consider anything to be a "Small Modular Reactor" unless it's almost entirely built in a factory. The term SMR is now being stretched and abused, IMHO.

@DjangoWexler Also, we won't do sequestration just anywhere. Large carbon capture projects that involve geological sequestration tend to be looking where the geography is well suited for that. Sometimes even at old, played-out oil & gas fields.

@DjangoWexler That's true. We have learned a lot about drilling, though. Drilling for fracking had something like a 6-7% annual cost improvement rate (it may have bottomed out since then). So the sequestration side at least gets to draft on an already existing industry and tech stack.
@joeszaka Yes indeed!  One of the figures I used came from there.

@DjangoWexler The capture is just harder. You have to move an extremely large volume of air, maximize surface contact, capture CO2 that's fairly low concentration, then separate it out into a concentrated CO2 stream. The sequestration moves a much lower volume of stuff.

@rob_carlson I do think floating has an advantage over fixed-bottom offshore wind in this way. When I talk to floating offshore startups, many are focused on modular pieces that are factory manufactured, and then assembly in harbor, as you say.  I'm more optimistic about it than SMRs.

@DjangoWexler Most of the cost isn't the sequestration.  It's actually the capture from air.  The sequestration might be $10-20/ton.  The capture is hundreds / ton. And alas, for most methods, the input energy is mostly heat rather than electricity (but there are some variations on this).
@rob_carlson Thanks, Rob.

@DjangoWexler There are some DAC systems that look like they would be: 1) More modular, with each module built in a factory;  2) Lower part count per module.  There's still always some field construction. But those are the ones I'm more optimistic about seeing faster cost declines in.

Note: This thread applies to housing as well. The main driver of housing cost increases is simply that we don't build enough due to NIMBY. But we could also lower "construction" costs through more factory assembly of pre-fab elements assembled on site.
@SnoozeButtonBen Great way to summarize it. Thanks.

I think Joe has an excellent point here. I expect point-source CCS, especially for *existing* plants, to have a much lower learning rate than solar or batteries or hydrogen electrolyzers.  A similar risk exists with *most* (but not all) DAC technologies.
@DanDelanis Thanks. I'm glad it was useful!

8. This doesn't just apply to nuclear.  Wind power has a slower learning rate than solar in part because there's more in-field assembly. Ocean energy techs also tend to involve more in-field assembly. For all, my advice is: Build all you can in a factory. Minimize assembly.

7. This topic comes up frequently for me when talking to next-gen nuclear startups.  One of my first questions is always: How much do you build in the factory vs assemble in the field? A shocking number aren't able to answer this question. Yet it's key for costs.

6. The implication of this is that, if we want low costs, we should build everything we can in factories, and do as little assembly in the field as is humanly possible.  Of course, it's sometimes not possible to get field assembly down to zero. But minimize it.

5. What's worse is that mega-project construction shows not just an increase in cost, but also a much higher likelihood and size of cost overrun when compared to highly modular projects made of repeatable units built in a factory. https://t.co/Gsoarscs5l

4. *Construction* costs, however, don't show such a trend. Brian Potter at Construction Physics has a post today asking, "Does Construction Ever Get Cheaper?"  The answer is pretty much no.  https://t.co/KXQ5VtQIqJ

3. Similar phenomena to solar appear in semiconductors, automobiles, aircraft, batteries, wind power, consumer electronics, and pretty much any mass-manufactured good. (With differing slopes.) The seminal paper on this was written in 2008. https://t.co/WHwI13QGW5

2. The learning rate / Wright's Law is now a widely understood phenomenon in clean energy. Every doubling of scale of simple (low part count), factory-manufactured goods leads to a fairly constant rate of cost decline. E.g., in solar:  https://t.co/W7Osf9Sm4l

1. A short thread on a fundamental trend in economics of physical stuff that's highly relevant to the conversation about nuclear & renewables:  
A. Manufacturing things gets cheaper with scale. 
B. Constructing things in the field gets more expensive with time.

@CJHandmer @scottleibrand The critical distance, and the slope of value increase for the transmission depend on the correlation of weather patterns over distance in that area. Similarly, the max duration of storage needed also depends upon the man length and depth of renewables variability in that area.

@CJHandmer @scottleibrand Physical or economic? China has UHVDC lines 3400 km long. The value of transmission (in a renewables-heavy world) goes up with distance as you become less coupled to regional weather patterns.
@scottleibrand @CJHandmer A further problem is that in many of these areas with long dark winters, population density is high, and locally siting 5x as much solar as you need is implausible. 2/

@scottleibrand @CJHandmer Scott hits a key point here. For places with little variability, where you can get by with hours of storage, storage will win. 

For areas where you need days of weeks of storage, and where solar production may vary by 5x or more between summer and winter, transmission. /1

1. This is correct. Fusion is likely to have extremely high CapEx initially. Even with fuel costs of essentially zero, the overall cost of electricity will depend on the cost to build fusion reactors. That's likely to be high initially. And we don't know how fast it will drop.

8. Overall, we have the technology and the economics to deploy a LOT of solar, batteries, and wind power (and other clean energy tech as well). But we have structural impediments that slow down this buildout & sometimes block it. We invented those processes. We need to fix them.

7. Clean energy impediment #3 is monopoly utility business models. Monopoly utilities that own both the power generation AND the wires have little incentive to allow the cheapest power from outside their regions to reach their customers. We need to seriously reform this.

6. Clean energy impediment #2 is transmission. Renewables benefit *more* from long-range transmission than fossil fuels. HVDC transmission tech is here, efficient, and cost-effective. Why don't we do it? Oh, it's all about permitting and NIMBY. Fix this.

5. Clean energy impediment #1 is permitting. At the federal, state, local level in the US, & similarly in Europe, the permitting process makes it easy to stall, delay, or outright reject renewable project. NIMBY is an enemy of climate progress. We need massive permitting reform.
4. That said, it's not all turning up roses. There are three major impediments to renewables:

6. Even so, it's going to be a wild ride for lithium. With EV demand surging, lithium demand is going to exceed supply for years to come.

5. The most likely outcome is that we'll see a surge in new lithium production, in part using new Direct Lithium Extraction (DLE) technologies like those from @energyx , @Lilac_Solutions , @StandardLithium , and many others. These should shorten the time to boost lithium supply

4. For mobility, though, lithium is still king. Companies like CATL are working on sodium-ion batteries that need no lithium. They look promising on cost, but it's less clear how well they'll do on energy density. Sodium is 3x heavier than lithium. https://t.co/4b629MSS8m

3. Solutions: For stationary storage, non-lithium battery chemistries become attractive. For stationary storage, this helps companies like @ESS_info which use iron based chemistries. Other beneficiaries are Zinc based batteries, carbon batteries, and a variety of others.

3. Many battery manufacturers (& auto OEMs) have locked up supply in long term contracts, so they're not being but immediately by this lithium price surge. But for those who didn't the spot market is brutal. And new lithium supply takes an average of 4 years to bring online.

2. There's ~850g of lithium carbonate / kwh of li-ion battery. At $62k / ton of LCE, that's ~$50/kwh of cost at the cell level. A cell used to cost $100/kwh. This run up in LCE costs has increased cell costs by as much as 40%. Though other factors are still driving cost down.

6/ If you are sincere in working to make a better world, we have common ground. Let's try to find it. 

If you're just here to troll, demonstrate your superiority, or score points, I suggest you reconsider your priorities. 

Cheers.

5/ All that said, incessant attacks on others working towards solutions will eventually cause me to doubt the sincerity with which people are working to address climate change, or at least there judgement or temperament.

4/ But I believe we should mostly give *individuals* working on climate solutions the benefit of the doubt with respect to their intentions. I will debate people on facts, trends, & issues, but aim to treat them well as people if I believe they're sincere in seeking solutions.
3/ I do believe that all *ideas* are fair game for criticism, repugnant l especially when it comes with data.
2/ I'm not perfect. I get impatient and aggravated with certain voices and arguments, especially when they've been refuted repeatedly and have not updated based on data or counterarguments.

1/ On infighting in the climate world: I'd rather spend my time building and advocating for climate solutions, and cheering on those doing the same (even if they're making different bets than I am) than bashing people working towards solutions with a different theory of change.

7/7 For context, I'm a climate startup investor. Given the actual meaning of ESG, making my fund into an ESG fund is completely non-interesting, and in fact, quite unattractive. And funds, vehicles, or companies which claim ESG will now attract additional scrutiny from me.

6/7 The net result of this is that it's now clear that ESG (or at least, S&P's criteria) has nothing to do with the impact - positive or negative - that a company has on society or humanity. It may mean something to some investors, but it is in no way a moral or impact measure.

5/7 Whatever ones opinion on Elon Musk is (and mine is complicated) it's just clear that Tesla has driven the decarbonization of transportation more than any other company on earth, while Exxon has mostly worked to oppose that decarbonization.

4/7 In an Orwellian twist, Tesla was also dropped from S&Ps ESG impact because of its "Lack of a low-carbon strategy". That is, to use a technical term, FUBAR. F*d Up Beyond All Recognition. https://t.co/bT82A8RIXq
3/7 Tesla was dropped from S&P's ESG impact *partially* because of labor practices and alleged racist incidents at its Fremont factory.  Okay.

2/7 What I've come to understand (and didn't before) is that ESG definitions have nothing to do with impact, and everything to do with risk to investors. While many investors understand this, I'd warrant that the majority (and the general public) do not.  https://t.co/uIv4rz3jsV https://t.co/mtbdFgFqKa

17. A useful explanatory thread on this recent study and the last 3 years of studies showing that we've bent the curve is here, from @hausfath https://t.co/Vuo4DKeya3
16. The full nature paper with this newest modeling study (showing ~1.9 degrees C of warming if all nations fulfill their pledges) is here: https://t.co/uoqE19sY4J

15. While I've used the past few tweets on controversial opinions, I want to come back to the very good news. Signs are that we've bent the curve of future warming from apocalyptic (4-6 degrees) to very survivable (~2 degrees). This is fantastic news.

14. I do not advocate deploying solar geo-engineering today. We simply don't know enough. I do advocate funding the research needed to fully understand its effects and side-effects. Today we spend maybe $10m / year on it. We should boost this R&D budget to ~$1 billion / year.

13. Solar geo-engineering could hold temperatures down a few tenths of a degree, at a cost of mere billions per year, giving us time to decarbonize without losing fragile ecosystems. All other solutions cost trillions, not billions.

12. As I wrote above, we have missed 1.5 degrees  through decarbonization alone. And while 2 C is very survivable, it comes with real losses. If we want to stay below 1.5 C, the only plausible path at this point is solar radiation management geo-engineering.

11. What kind of tools? We need tools to be able to intervene in the case of rapid methane release, or rapid sea ice loss in the arctic, or rapid glacier melt. More than any of those, we need to do the research to develop solar geo-engineering.

10. Fourth, we need to develop tools to guard against tail risks. While these new studies show warming will *probably* stay below 2C, there are error bars, and there are still risks of feedback loops that cause faster warming than expected. We need tools to knock off that risk.

9. Third, we need to develop tools to intervene in fragile ecosystems to make them more resilient to climate effects. If you care about, e.g., coral reefs, this is no longer optional. They need our help to survive and thrive, even at 1.5-2 degrees C.

8. Second, we ought to find ways to even further accelerate this timeline for decarbonization. Every 10th of a degree matters. Bending the curve further to 1.8 or 1.7 degrees matters. The sooner we get to net zero, the better.

7. Even so, there is much more work to be done.  First, we must actually achieve the decarbonization that matches national pledges, meaning net zero in the rich world by ~2050, and in China and India by 2060 & 2070. That will require tech, policy, and economic innovation.

6. So this new paper, and this wave of modeling studies, are extremely good news. Civilization will not end at 2 degrees C. There's every reason to believe that median human welfare will be much higher in 2100, at this level of warming, than it is today.
5. Even if we were to stay below 1.5 degrees C (which we're not), we would have major challenges with increased extreme weather, fires, & potential loss of almost all coral reefs.

4. We now see a line of sight to staying below 2 degrees C. Now, our aspirations have also lifted. We'd like to stay below 1.5 degrees C of warming. And we have to be clear. We are not going to stay below 1.5 degrees C through decarbonization. It's no longer plausible.

3. For context, when I started in climate around 2010, expectations were that we would see 4 -  6 degrees Celsius of warming by 2100. That would be truly apocalyptic warming, with a severe chance of kicking off major feedback loops, and dramatic disruptions to civilization.

2. This is the latest of more than a dozen studies over the last 3 years that have found that we've bent the curve of future warming down significantly. Here's a summary of those papers, from @hausfath and @ClimateFran https://t.co/fjU5R6CgMp https://t.co/nX5Leeeg2X

1. A thread on climate hope: There is an extremely important and hope-filled climate paper out in Nature today. It finds that, if all the countries of the world fulfilled their climate commitments, the world would most likely limit climate change to just under 2 degrees C. https://t.co/KmWXeBZ7No

It's asymmetric warfare. Ukraine doesn't need $1B/day in arms to win. But it likely needs a lot more than we've sent.
@BrettKing Belt and Road is floundering though, right?  I do think it's an interesting point on the energy trade. Though it will be a couple decades before that declines really materially.
@futurepundit I hope that's true.  I'm not fully convinced of that yet. But I do see multiple people making that assertion. I haven't dug into the numbers or assumptions yet.

15/15 What I hope both Biden and European leaders see is that Ukraine *can* win, if (and only if) we give them every bit of material support possible. We are trending in the right direction, but there is much more we can do. Please do it, for the sake of Ukraine and the world.
14/15 I also respect that Biden takes very seriously the risk of nuclear conflict, and is playing a very steady hand in not escalating this conflict. (Even if I disagree.)

13/15 To close, I want to say that I'm overall impressed by Biden's response to Putin's invasion, and that of Europe. Biden did well to sound the alarm, to "pre-bunk" Putin's false flag plans and lies, and to rally the world to severe sanctions and real arms support of Ukraine.

12/15 But China is also drawing a lesson from this that the US and its allies will likely NOT militarily intervene in the case of a Chinese invasion of Taiwan. That is not the conclusion we want Xi to come to. Leading China to believe that increases the risk of Chinese invasion.

11/15 China is watching Putin's invasion of Ukraine and our response closely.  Xi is surely drawing many lessons from this. Many of those lessons will discourage him from invading Taiwan. Xi now must fear crippling Western sanctions and the stout resolve of Taiwanese people.

10/15 Finally, let's talk about China and Taiwan, and how the response of the US and the West to Ukraine sets the precedent for future conflict over Taiwan, and can encourage or discourage a Chinese military invasion of Taiwan.

9/15 The best way to deter Putin from escalating is to show him overwhelming force. Arm Ukraine fully. Train Ukraine to use advanced US weapons. Move US forces aggressively into nearby NATO countries. Signal clearly that chem or bio weapons will lead to a US military response.

8/15 If Putin uses chemical or bio weapons in Ukraine, the situation becomes even more dangerous. Does the US respond militarily then? And if not, what signal does that send Putin? It tells him he can do it again. Maybe it even leads him to believe he could use a tactical nuke.

7/15 The US's lack of a plan to arm Ukraine to win, coupled with our insistence that we won't directly enter the war, under any circumstances, tell Putin that he can escalate without any direct response from the US. That invites him to do so.

6/15 By not giving Ukraine overwhelming force, and demonstrating how serious we are, we signal to Putin that he can escalate things further, without a firm response. The odds that he'll use chemical and biological weapons are much lower if he believes we we'll respond seriously.

5/15 By not fully committing to arm Ukraine with absolutely any tool (short of US soldiers) needed to win the war, the US is, at minimum, increasing the number of civilians slaughtered by Putin.  And worse, we're making the situation more dangerous, in both Europe and Asia.

4/15 At the same time, there's a huge amount more we can do to arm Ukraine with weapons, training, and humanitarian supplies, to given Ukrainians every chance to fully defeat Putin's invading army. Every useful conventional weapon ought to be on offer, in quantity. With training.

3/15 My perception is that President Biden, and much of the US left (of which I'm a part) are focused on avoiding near term direct confrontation of Russia because they fear the risk of it triggering nuclear conflict.  This is obviously understandable.

2/15 The core tests of any plan for US support of Ukraine need to be:
A) Does this give Ukraine what it needs in order to outright win the war, and destroy Putin's invading army.
B) While avoiding nuclear confrontation, now and in the future.

1/15 The Biden admin has done far better in supporting Ukraine than I expected. That said, what Cruz is asserting here rings true: It is not at all clear that Biden is aiming for Ukraine to actually win this war. And that is a profound mistake.

Whether Covid came to humans due to a lab leak or (as is most likely) through animal to human crossovers in the market, the best path forward is to increase investments in pandemic preparedness, including pandemic surveillance and especially transparency. /fin

There will continue to be more analysis of Covid's origin. We may never find a smoking gun either for the wet market hypothesis or the lab leak hypothesis. But the evidence is now pretty strongly on the side of the market crossover. 13/n

This also doesn't negate the argument that we should have more care with viral research with potentially dangerous pathogens. We should demand high standards of care and of transparency in such research. China has failed on the transparency point, at least. 12/n
This also does not let the Chinese government off the hook. The Chinese government has been far too resistant to transparency here, and needs to be more open with data. 11/n

This doesn't mean that we shouldn't take the lab leak hypothesis seriously. I dismissed it overly quickly when it first emerged. And I do think its popularity was driven in part by politics. But it's a valid hypothesis that deserves engagement. The data now point against it. 10/n

None of this evidence provides absolute proof that the virus crossed over from animals in the market. It's still theoretically possible that this happened via a lab leak. But the evidence is much more consistent with animal to human crossover of Covid in the market. 9/n

The third line of evidence is the genetic evidence that two distinct covid strains crossed over from animals to humans in November or December of 2019. This is more consistent with an animal population with many points of contact with many humans than an isolated lab leak. 8/n

Second line of evidence is that even within the market, there's a connection between the work location of people who caught Covid and places where scientists found coronavirus in environmental samples taken from surfaces, meat, mice, and stray animals. 7/n https://t.co/z4xisHdBsL

By contrast, the Wuhan Institute of Virology is more than ten miles away from the market, and not on the map in the previous tweet at all. From a previous study, you can see WIVs location vs the location of cases and the market. 6/n https://t.co/7QUadv46Js
First, December Covid cases in Wuhan geographically clustered around the Wuhan Seafood Market (which sold many animals, not just seafood). 5/n https://t.co/wV01HglBoX
There are three lines of evidence here that point to animal to human crossovers (multiple) at the Wuhan wet market as the likely introduction of Covid to humans. 4/n

This probabalistic analysis of early Covid spread doesn't produce a smoking gun. But it is much more consistent with spread from animals to humans in the Wuhan market than it is with a lab leak origin. 3/n

"‚ÄúWhen you look at all of the evidence together, it‚Äôs an extraordinarily clear picture that the pandemic started at the Huanan market,‚Äù said¬†Michael Worobey, an evolutionary biologist at the University of Arizona and a co-author of both new studies." 2/n

Thread. Two large, sophisticated, data-driven analysis of the genetics and location of early Covid cases in Wuhan find that it's extremely likely that Covid crossed over from animals at the market. At least twice. 1/n 
https://t.co/8ROOcwLsJv

This doesn't mean that they're doomed. Humanity could intervene to save them. We could selectively breed coral species to better survive heat, for example. (And it's just one study, which could be off.) But it does increase the urgency and level of risk here. 4/

Previously we were thought that corals would be almost wiped out by 2C of warming. This new research uses higher resolution modeling to find that even at 1.5C of warming, most reefs would be exposed to heat-driven bleaching events too often to recover. https://t.co/yHm3BOIrHP 3/

Coral reef systems are the "rainforests of the sea", hosting an estimated 25% of the biodiversity in the oceans. They also provide the protein (fish) that roughly 500 million people depend on. Theyn protect coastal areas from storms and erosion. And they're beautiful.  2/

Of all the ecological impacts of climate change, the one that scares me the most is the loss of coral reefs. New research suggests this could happen much earlier than we thought (at 1.5C of warming, or ~20 years from now, rather than at 2C of warming). https://t.co/yHm3BOIrHP /1

Uncertainty in climate is real. The numbers I shared earlier are central estimates of warming at specific greenhouse gas accumulations in the atmosphere. But there are still feedback loops that expand the error bars significantly. The best way to avoid them is to warm less!

@MoisheLettvin Hey, Mo! Crypto electricity use is rising fast. Crypto may contribute close somewhere close to a percent of all greenhouse gas emissions this year. But ultimately, electricity is going to do zero carbon, so crypto will as well.

(A number of these charts on climate SSPs extracted from this helpful thread by @hausfath https://t.co/M2cQGufRke )

At the end of the day, there's a huge amount of work to do to decarbonize our civilization and halt warming. Technology provides us an incredible tool, but it's one we have to harness through policy and economics. We've bent the climate curve already. And we have much more to do.

So that's where I see our current trajectory. Somewhere between 2.2 - 2.7C of warming (with uncertainty on top of that). I believe we can bend that curve even further, and close to 2C, with concerted effort. 2C itself is bad, in a myriad of ways. But we can survive it. 6/n

Where does that put us in warming? SSP4-3.4 leads to about 2.2C of warming, plus or minus some tenths of a degree. SSP2-4.5 (what I consider a worst case) leads to ~2.7C of warming, plus or minus. (Both are on the right graph.)  5/n https://t.co/ps27P4neEu
SSP2-4.5 has emissions not even peaking until 2040, and dropping 75% by 2100. (Yellow line.) We can do better than that. 4/n https://t.co/ldtzDvyYHT

Even net zero by 2050 looks daunting (though within our power to achieve). If I were to look at our technical & policy progress, I see us being able to achieve something close to SSP 4-3.4: Cutting emissions in half by 2050, and to zero by 2080. Worst case- IMHO is SSP2-4.5. 3/n https://t.co/8PRDNFrgkA

@NoahBakerLong @MikeGrunwald Yes. The reason those state policies haven't moved the needle on CCS (or, say, multi-day storage, or power to hydrogen) is that their dates for 100% clean are still so distant.

@MikeGrunwald The direct subsidies for projects aren't really effective demand policies, though. What we lack so far is something that forces decarbonization of power or other industries on a timescale soon enough to motivate large-scale investments in CCS or alternative technologies.
@MargrietKuijper Mandates, decarbonization standards, high carbon prices. Any of those.

Some climate techs (solar, wind, EVs) get disruptively cheap at scale. Others, like hydrogen & CCS, may drop in price tremendously but always require policy support. Either way, at the early stage, if there's no policy mandate that scales them, they'll never get cheap. /fin

If you want a climate solution to scale, there must be market demand for it. There must be someone who'll pay for it. Carbon capture has failed thus far because there is no demand, and thus no business model. The primary way to fix that is with policy. The tech will follow. 1/3

@dpksmith Integrating any offshore resource into the grid has its challenges (for example, integrating North Sea offshore wind into Germany).  That said, it shouldn't be a whole lot worse with floating. Most of the HVDC cost is in converter stations rather than cabling. (At that distance)

@dpksmith @JesseJenkins It's a question of cost per unit of electricity generation. Floating platforms are massive, and going to get bigger as floating turbines get bigger. But still headed for less cost per MW of turbine, and even less per MWh produced.

@dpksmith Opening up more area is one advantage. But it's also a matter of opening up areas with higher wind speeds and more consistent wind. The North Sea is a rare location that combines a shallow bottom, great winds, and close to shore. More generally, you get better winds further out.

@dpksmith @JesseJenkins There is at least one design where more of the installation happens at the site (Equinor's spar bouy). But most designs (thus far) involve towing the assembled turbine. See, for example, https://t.co/IXY6GXWJo4

@SolarInMASS @JesseJenkins Yes. I should have said "no monopiles to drive into the seabed". Floating wind still uses anchors and tethers. But those are cheaper and easier to install than monopiles. (They just need to keep the turbine in position rather than supporting its weight.)

@isabelleboemeke @robertwiblin Yes. H2 is a very small molecule (it leaks through steel, and embrittles it), and also very low energy density per volume at atmospheric pressure and temp. This bargain, of allowing fossil power plants that have CCS to participate in the Clean Electricity Standard, *scaled by the amount they actually reduce emissions!* has the potential to win Manchin over, while not meaningfully weakening a CES of 80% clean electricity by 2030. Fin

That said, fossil generators have to be judged based on emissions post carbon capture, as well as methane leakage across the whole value chain from well to plant.

Gas + CCS projects won't be zero emissions. How they count in a CES should be based on actual emissions & leaks. 5/N
4. New designs like NetPower (https://t.co/yRpkpYfc61) could make natural gas with carbon capture cheap and flexible. We'd be foolish to dismiss these completely. 4/N
3. Natural gas + CCS, on the other hand, may actually work. And it may be a useful tool for providing seasonal and multi-day generation to complement renewables and hourly storage. 3/N

Why would I say this? 
1. Manchin's support is absolutely required in order to pass a Clean Electricity Standard, or to pass any reconciliation bill at all.

2. Coal is already increasingly uncompetitive. Adding CCS will make it even more expensive. Coal is dead, either way. 2/N

Thread: Joe Manchin is disturbed by the climate provisions in the budget bill that would phase out fossil fuels. He's wrong to be disturbed. Nevertheless, Dems should try to win him over by allowing coal and gas powerplants, IF they're fitted with CCS, to participate in a CES 1/N

@DoctorVive @sunny_hundal @mattywin85 @KetanJ0 @Marcusdstewart @mims @hausfath @guardian @JohnKerry I say this from personal experience. I spent the last decade communicating the cost trends in solar/wind/batteries/EVs - and how they'll disrupt fossil fuel consumption - to these sorts of companies. And I've seen that once a company believes this, their investments shift.

@KetanJ0 @navgattu @DoctorVive @mattywin85 @sunny_hundal @Marcusdstewart @mims @hausfath @guardian @JohnKerry My comments aren't intended to give anyone solace, or to defend oil and gas companies.

My point is just this: There's value in getting O&G companies to invest in clean energy. We've already seen benefits (offshore & floating wind). And it's worth continuing to encourage them.

@KetanJ0 @navgattu @DoctorVive @mattywin85 @sunny_hundal @Marcusdstewart @mims @hausfath @guardian @JohnKerry Exxon and Chevron made bad choices. They did not believe future trends on clean energy would continue. That has cost them. The European majors were a bit faster to realize what's happening (though they're still underestimating the pace).

@navgattu @DoctorVive @mattywin85 @KetanJ0 @sunny_hundal @Marcusdstewart @mims @hausfath @guardian @JohnKerry They will continue to act to maximize profits. I agree 100%. And the way to convince them (or any other business) to invest in the clean future is to make it very clear that it's in their financial best interest.

@KetanJ0 @DoctorVive @mattywin85 @sunny_hundal @Marcusdstewart @mims @hausfath @guardian @JohnKerry I'm not saying that Equinor are angels, or even judging them as a whole as good or bad.  I'm saying that their early investments in, e.g., floating wind, had a *massive* positive externality for the world, by making that tech viable. And that we should try to replicate that.

@DoctorVive @mattywin85 @KetanJ0 @sunny_hundal @Marcusdstewart @mims @hausfath @guardian @JohnKerry It's the same message I've given to banks, private equity firms, sovereign wealth funds. As the data becomes more and more clear - that clean energy continues to plunge in cost, and policy continues to advance - they increasingly see investing in it as a matter of survival.

@DoctorVive @mattywin85 @KetanJ0 @sunny_hundal @Marcusdstewart @mims @hausfath @guardian @JohnKerry When I talk to fossil fuel companies my message is never about them helping the world.

My message is: This transition is happening. Plunging clean energy costs are going to disrupt your business. Policy is going to keep advancing. Get on board and profit. Or don't, and fail.

@DoctorVive @mattywin85 @KetanJ0 @sunny_hundal @Marcusdstewart @mims @hausfath @guardian @JohnKerry No. You don't have to trust or like them at all to believe that they'll do more clean energy in the future. You just have to believe that the economics of it will become clear. That there is no future in oil, and that the only energy companies that survive will be clean ones.

@DoctorVive @mattywin85 @KetanJ0 @sunny_hundal @Marcusdstewart @mims @hausfath @guardian @JohnKerry You don't have to trust or like fossil fuel companies to see that there are some benefits for the world if they use their capabilities to deploy clean energy, and to scale nascent clean energy technologies.

@DoctorVive @mattywin85 @KetanJ0 @sunny_hundal @Marcusdstewart @mims @hausfath @guardian @JohnKerry It's not faith. Forecasts of future solar cost declines can't be taken for granted, though. Too much rides on this. DOE's new funding for advanced solar technologies is thus extremely welcome. And indeed, we should invest far more in clean energy R&D, as @vsiv and others have argued.. 7/n

Historically, solar costs have beaten DOE's most aggressive cost targets. For example, solar costs hit DOE's SunShot targets 3 years earlier than DOE's goal.  https://t.co/dUrdnPAaap

This target may be similar. We may well hit these costs before DOE's target date. 6/n
This solar cost *target* is actually fairly similar to the solar cost *forecast* I made last year based on the rate at which solar costs have historically come down:  https://t.co/W7Osfa9WVT 5/n

In publishing this solar cost target, DOE is committing to working to make this cost reduction happen, with tens of millions of dollars in new R&D funding, especially for perovskite solar cells.  Read more here: https://t.co/VaDi2IIHvG 4/n

Hitting DOE's 2030 solar cost target would also mean that new solar electricity would cheaper than the operating cost of *existing* coal and natural gas plants (at least during daylight hours).  I talked about this as the 3rd Phase of Clean Energy:  https://t.co/WBVFSXPHAe  3/n
Achieving DOE's target of 60% cost reduction of solar by 2030 would make solar the cheapest source of electricity over most of the US.   2/n

The US Department of Energy has new solar cost targets:  2 cents / kwh in average locations (Kansas City, MO) by 2030. This is a phenomenal goal, welcome additional investment in advanced solar R&D, and also very plausible.  A short thread.   1/n https://t.co/wZmQ2SMwtJ

@jgkoomey @chrisnelder @GlobalEcoGuy @arilevaux It wouldn't surprise me if China outlaws bitcoin at some point. Yet making it illegal is not the same as the technology not existing.

@jgkoomey @chrisnelder @GlobalEcoGuy @arilevaux I have yet to see a blockchain application in the energy space that I thought made sense. (At least in the developed world.)  In developed nations, there are entities like ISOs that are trustworthy, and plenty of ways to transact both data and money.

@jgkoomey @chrisnelder @GlobalEcoGuy @arilevaux I agree. The supply chain case is not a really strong one to me, unless part of the supply chain comes from a place where there's a high risk of corruption or falsification. Even then, blockchain is only part of the solution. You need validation of the data being entered.

@jgkoomey @chrisnelder @GlobalEcoGuy @arilevaux I'll be honest: Most blockchain applications I've seen have not made a lot of sense.

Those that do make sense to me have these attributes:
1. You don't trust a central authority.
2. You need an immutable (or at least, tamper-evident) record.
3. You want censorship-resistance.

@jgkoomey @chrisnelder @GlobalEcoGuy @arilevaux To put it another way: The world is going to move to digital money. China certainly is. In the totalitarian parts of the world where civil liberties are scarce, I'd rather at least some of that money be decentralized than under complete state control.

@jgkoomey @chrisnelder @GlobalEcoGuy @arilevaux I wouldn't consider myself a bitcoin bro. (I have a very small amount of it.) The main societal value I see is that of "censorship-resistant money" in places like China, Iran, or Venezuela, where the state is anything but liberal.
@DjangoWexler (Though a better use of that money would be to fund R&D.  Or to subsidize the deployment of renewables onto the grid such that they displace fossil fuels.)

@DjangoWexler But if, say, someone wanted to spend a billion dollars a year buying specifically renewable electricity, and just grounded all of that electricity into the earth, it would actually accelerate the clean energy transition, by accelerating the learning-by-doing of renewables.

@DjangoWexler I'm not saying that buying solar electricity and throwing it away is the most *cost effective* way to make solar cheaper.  Just that it has that positive externality.

I'm also not saying that buying dirty electricity is good. It's not.

@DjangoWexler Here's how I'd put it:

Anything that increases demand for renewables (specifically) has the effect of making renewables cheaper, which accelerates the pace at which they displace fossil electricity.

@clawrence As mining difficulty goes up, there's more pressure for both efficiency and low electricity costs.

Coal is cheap. But the cheapest electricity contracts in the world are solar and wind. And they keep dropping in price. Why wouldn't most miners switch increasingly to them?
@GlobalEcoGuy @arilevaux Today, if the top 7 crypto currencies together use 59 TWh (most recent estimate), that amounts to ~0.3% of global electricity, or < 0.1% of global emissions.
@duncan__c Well, I do see environmentalists proposing that we ban crypto. I realize that's not your position.

@GlobalEcoGuy @arilevaux I'm all for encouraging efficiency. I'm all for pricing externalities. I'm not so much for dictating what people can and can't do.

And as I commented earlier, there's a real human rights benefit to censorship-resistant money (in, e.g. Venezuela, China, Iran).

@duncan__c Who's to say what's worthless? Is playing video games worthless? How about going on a vacation? 

Crypto does have some real value if you're in a place like China, Iran, or Venezuela. There's a real case for censorship-resistant money in parts of the world that aren't free.

@GlobalEcoGuy @arilevaux Finally, whenever I've dug into the math on bitcoin energy use or bitcoin emissions, I've been very dubious of some of the assumptions made on pretty flimsy data. Change some of those assumptions, and the picture is very different. (3/3)

@GlobalEcoGuy @arilevaux Secondly, flexible, price-sensitive electricity load is going to increasingly be served by renewables. (There's evidence that a lot of btc mining is renewable already.) That in turn will drive renewables down their learning curves, making them cheaper for everyone. (2/3)

@GlobalEcoGuy @arilevaux I'm not a bitcoin stan. I do see some value in censorship-resistant money in totalitarian parts of the world.

But in general, my POV is: We're going to use more electricity. We're not going to stop people from using electricity, even for frivolous things. (1/3)

If the US could reduce its carbon emissions by 90% (without lowering cost of doing so for other nations) that accomplishes roughly nothing.

If the US could lower the cost of clean electricity, heat, ag, & industry by 90%, that accomplishes everything. 

Fortunately, #1 --> #2.

I broadly agree with Bill Gates. Our greatest leverage is in making clean technology cheaper.

At the same time, after early stage R&D, actually deploying clean technologies has been the most sure-fire way of reducing the cost of replacing fossil fuels. 

We need more of both.

The world is poor, but getting richer. The incomes of those at the bottom quartile are rising faster than those of the top quartile.

Still, when we speak of economic justice or climate justice, the focus really ought to be on the *global* poor, in the global south.

@_jameshatfield_ Capital isn't really the bottleneck for clean energy or EVs.

It's demand. Keep making them cheaper. Keep fixing regulatory issues. Keep making them easier to buy. Then you'll see clean energy demand grow, and fossil demand shrink. That's the real virtuous cycle.

@_jameshatfield_ That tipping point is here for coal plants in the US and Europe. It may arrive soon for coal in China and Asia.

It's likely several years off for oil.  Oil demand will probably rebound quite a bit in 2022.  They'll say "see: Peak oil demand is a myth".  But it's still coming.

@timothyaclark When a bank is looking at lending to a project, they're looking at metrics like IRR, NPV, and future cashflows *of that project*. They also want to understand the stability of the project developer. But that's about earnings / profits of the developer, not stock price.

@_jameshatfield_ Divestment is a lot easier after you've seen fossil fuel company stocks crater and TSLA soar.  

What happens if oil company stocks get a big lift in 2022 from a rising economy and peak oil demand still being several years away?

@moskov @timothyaclark The ability of oil cos to invest in projects isn't restricted by their stock price - it's restricted by their balance sheet & cashflows.  Their ability to raise debt for the projects is restricted by the above + bank policies & bank estimates of future earnings.

@moskov @timothyaclark Essentially, almost every energy project you see - whether an oil drilling project or a solar farm - is actually its own corporation, with a capital stack descending from its "developers", earlier/higher risk investors (the equity investors), and cheap bank debt.

@moskov @timothyaclark I mean equity investors in a project.  It varies from project to project.  But typically you'll have some capital structure with:
- The core developer (an oil co)
- An project-level equity investor. (Often the oil co. Maybe a PE firm.)
- Half of more of the money as debt
@GregorMacdonald I know.  It's a foolish thing for me to focus energy on.  And you're right - there may be social effects or knock on effects I can't easily measure.
Amend.  Reducing fossil fuel demand is the real "divestment". And the best way to do that is to make clean energy and clean transport cheaper than fossil-fueled energy & transport.

Move chunks of your money to an easy-to-use green bank like @joinatmos, that uses deposits *only* to fund clean energy projects, and nothing else.  (Savings account only now. But much more is coming soon.) Start here: https://t.co/2sUZQ92Tes

@timothyaclark Nah. Not really. Lowering the stock price (if that even happens) doesn't impact the cost of capital. That's all about the balance sheet and actual profit/loss of the company.

I understand why people believe this. But it doesn't hold up when digging in.

I should add: I admire the heck out of everyone who fights for divestment of public fossil fuel company stocks. I understand & respect the ethical stance behind it.

Just saying: Focus your efforts even more on the banks, lenders, & equity investors that fund the actual projects.

@KenCaldeira @gnievchenko @hausfath @moskov The thing that's not appreciated here is that pure electric vehicles already frequently have lower operating costs / mile than gasoline. And will probably have lower capital costs in a handful of years.

@KenCaldeira @gnievchenko @hausfath @moskov For ground transport:

The hydrogen path will always have energy losses and extra costs (compared to full electric) at:
1. Electrolysis. 
2. Compression (for storage).
3. More moving parts on the vehicle.
4. Conversion back to electricity in the fuel cell.

@KenCaldeira @gnievchenko @hausfath @moskov I only really got into this field around 2010. But even then, the technology learning rates (my typical go to) strongly favored electric over hydrogen for the bulk of ground transport. Regardless of what official reports said. 

Every year, that evidence has grown stronger.
@pt @moskov @hausfath Today, in the US, Tesla superchargers will generally only charge Tesla's. (A few exceptions apply. But that's broadly what you can expect.)

@moskov @mikeydoubled @hausfath This is also an interesting space for startups. Turns out reliably knowing current battery performance is harder than one would think. (Or harder than I expected, anyway!) I've seen three pitches in the last couple months trying to address this.

@pt @moskov @hausfath One company to look at: Ample. They're building standard battery units that can go into any EV (after after-market mod to the EV). That way, battery swap stations only need one battery sku. 

I passed on their A round, though. Sky high valuation, and economics didn't make sense.
